thread.title: Who are the Tory candidates hoping so succeed Edward Garnier as Harborough MP? | Leicester Mercury
thread.title_full: Who are the Tory candidates hoping so succeed Edward Garnier as Harborough MP? | Leicester Mercury

title: Who are the Tory candidates hoping so succeed Edward Garnier as Harborough MP? | Leicester Mercury
text:
Who are the Tory candidates hoping to succeed Edward Garnier as Harborough MP? By danjmartin | Posted: May 04, 2017 0 COMMENTS SHARES Sir Edward Garnier will not fight the General Election Who are the Tory candidates hoping to succeed Edward Garnier as Harborough MP? X 
Copy link to paste in your message / 
The seat has a Tory majority of more than 19,000 and is widely considered a safe path into parliament for whoever is chosen to fight it on June 8. 
The Harborough Conservative Association is set to select a candidate tomorrow night but the website Conservative Home has reported on a shortlist of candidates. General Election 2017: Click HERE for everything you need to know 
The first hopeful, according to Conservative Home, is Tim Clark who is currently the Principal of Skinners' Academy in Hackney and was headmaster of Spalding High School in Lincolnshire. 
In 2005 he stood unsuccessfully against David Blunkett in Sheffield Brightside, and in 2014 he was a finalist in the Boston and Skegness selection. 
Read more: Harborough Tory MP Edward Garnier confirms he won't stand in the General Election 
The next is Helen Harrison, a district councillor in East Northamptonshire, who runs her own physiotherapy business, having previously spent much of her career in the NHS. 
She fought the Ashfield seat in the 2015 General Election and is director of the pro-Brexit campaign group Grassroots Out. 
Neil O'Brien is the third candidate. 
He is the former director of Policy Exchange and Open Europe. 
He advises on industrial strategy and the Northern Powerhouse in the Prime Minister's Policy Unit and was a special adviser to George Osborne in the Treasury from 2012 to 2016. 
The Mercury understands CCHQ ordered a closed list of candidates immediately barring local hopefuls like former police and crime commissioner candidate Neil Bannister, Harborough-based East Midlands MEP Emma McClarkin and Harborough District Council leader Blake Pain. 
It is understood the decision to exclude candidates with stronger links to the constituency has caused resentment among some local activists. 
Oadby and Wigston borough councillor Teck Khong had indicated he would have liked to fight the seat having previously been removed from a Tory candidates list. 
However he did not make the shortlist and has apparently quit the party and is now listed as an independent councillor. 
He has not responded to a Mercury request for a comment. 
The Conservative Party has declined to comment on selection matters ahead of the meeting. 
The Liberal Democrats have selected Zuffar Haq to fight the seat and Labour have chosen Andy Thomas.
